requirements:
Basic To-Do List Website Requirements
User Interface:

Simple input field to add new tasks quickly.

List display area showing tasks clearly.

Checkboxes or toggles to mark tasks as completed.

Edit and delete options for existing tasks.

Responsive design for use on both desktop and mobile devices.

Task Management:

Ability to add, edit, and delete tasks.

Mark tasks as complete or incomplete.

Option to prioritize or categorize tasks.

Save tasks persistently (local storage or backend database).

User Experience:

Clear visual differentiation between completed and pending tasks.

Easy navigation and intuitive controls.

Option to reorder tasks by drag and drop or priority.

Technical Requirements:

Responsive front-end using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Optional backend for user authentication and task storage (using database).

Cross-browser compatibility.

Performance optimized for fast load and smooth interactions.

functional_requirements.description: Allows a user to add a new task to their to-do list.
acceptance_criteria: An input field is displayed at the top of the page.
User can type a task description into the input field.
Pressing 'Enter' or clicking an 'Add' button adds the task to the list.
The input field is cleared after adding a task.

functional_requirements.description: Allows a user to mark a task as complete or incomplete.
acceptance_criteria: A checkbox or similar control is visible next to each task.
Clicking the checkbox toggles the task's completion status.
Completed tasks are visually distinct from pending tasks (e.g., strikethrough text, faded color).

functional_requirements.description: Allows a user to modify the description of an existing task.
acceptance_criteria: An 'Edit' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Edit' allows the user to modify the task's description in-place.
Saving the changes updates the task in the list.

functional_requirements.description: Allows a user to remove a task from the list.
acceptance_criteria: A 'Delete' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Delete' prompts the user for confirmation.
Upon confirmation, the task is permanently removed from the list.

functional_requirements.description: Ensures that the user's tasks are saved between sessions.
acceptance_criteria: Tasks added, edited, deleted, or marked as complete persist after the browser is closed and reopened.
The application uses browser local storage to save task data.

functional_requirements.description: The user interface must be fully responsive and adapt to various device viewports.
acceptance_criteria: The application layout adjusts cleanly for mobile, tablet, and desktop screen sizes.
All functionality is accessible and usable on all supported screen sizes.

non_functional_requirements.description: The web application should load quickly and provide a smooth user experience without noticeable delays in interactions.
metrics: Initial page load time under 2 seconds.
UI response to user actions (add, complete, delete) under 100ms.

non_functional_requirements.description: The interface must be intuitive and easy to use for a general audience with minimal to no instruction.
metrics: A new user can successfully add and complete a task within 30 seconds.
Controls for adding, editing, and deleting tasks are clearly visible and understandable.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application must render and function correctly across the latest versions of major web browsers.
metrics: Full support for the latest two versions of Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari, and Microsoft Edge.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should be usable by people with disabilities, following web accessibility standards.

backend: Node.js with Express (for optional database version)
database: PostgreSQL or MongoDB (for optional database version)
devops: GitHub Pages or Netlify (for static hosting)

risks: Data Loss: Since data is stored in local storage, users can lose their data if they clear their browser cache or switch devices.
Scope Creep: Requests for additional features like user accounts, due dates, or categories could expand the project beyond its initial low-complexity scope and timeline.
Browser Inconsistencies: Minor differences in JavaScript or CSS implementation across browsers may require specific fixes.
assumptions: The initial version will not require user authentication. All data will be stored in the browser's local storage.
The application will manage a single to-do list, not multiple lists per user.
The target users will be using modern, up-to-date web browsers that support HTML5, CSS3, and ES6 JavaScript.
The scope is limited to the core features of a to-do list; advanced features like reminders, attachments, or collaboration are out of scope.
